conversation.content: Twenty-three thousand dollars. [confused] That can't be right. I've gone over these statements three times now and the numbers just— [anxious] they don't match what Sandra's been telling me. [pause] Every quarter she'd sit right there, in that chair, showing me how well the fund was doing. [bitter] "You're all set for retirement, don't worry about a thing." [stuttering] I-I trusted her completely. She's been handling our benefits for what, twelve years? [angry] God, I'm such an idiot. Look at these withdrawals— [very quickly] processing fees, administrative adjustments, consulting charges— [furious] none of this was ever mentioned! [sigh] She looked me in the eye. Every single meeting. [very sad] We talked about her kids, about her daughter getting into college. I wrote her a recommendation letter! [laugh] And the whole time she was just... what, stealing from me? From all of us? [shaky voice] My retirement. The money I've been putting away since I was twenty-five. [frustrated] How do you do that to someone? [pause] I need to call the others. Jenkins, Maria, probably everyone in the department. [very quietly] We're all going to be short. [angry] Twenty-three thousand dollars, and that's just what I can prove. [trailing off] Sandra, how could you...

subject: Discovering your trusted employee benefits broker has been skimming money from your retirement fund
